The extra framework cation type exhibits a profound influence on the CO2 capture capacity and the pore volume of zeolites. The functionalization of amine sites with electron-withdrawing or bulky groups leads to very low adsorption heats. The methodology of pore confinement makes the fabrication of scalable and efficient zeolite adsorbents possible so that they can be applied in size-selective separations. The trade-off between the adsorption capacity, diffusion kinetics, and mechanical stability of zeolites remains a great challenge in their industrial applications. Furthermore, the existence of moisture greatly influences the CO2 capture performance of zeolites-based materials as they are not useful at higher operation temperatures with low CO2 partial pressure due to the physical adsorption mechanism.
Fig. 17 A brief summary of the research activities on zeolite-based CO2 adsorbents12,115–119,122 (Reproduced from ref. 117 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 118 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 122 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2019; reproduced from ref. 116 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 119 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018).
2.2.4 MOF-based adsorbents. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a novel category of crystalline nano-porous materials,123,124 which are composed of transition metal ions connected by bridging organic ligands to generate porous structures, with various physical and chemical properties, such as ultrahigh specific surface areas and large porosities. The wide-ranging alternative possibilities of organic linkers and transition metals lead to the development of various MOFs with tunable adsorption sites so as to enable selective and energy-efficient CO2 capture. MOFs have particularly attracted attention due to their typically high pore volume and specific surface area, which offer abundant void space and numerous adsorption sites to host CO2. The exceptional tunability of MOFs provides chemically and structurally tailorable nanopores as they possess optimal adsorption sites with careful positioning towards selective CO2 physisorption (<200 °C).125 CO2 adsorption is expected to be critically influenced by both the topology and chemistry of the MOF pores. To enhance the CO2 selectivity and affinity, Anderson and coworkers investigated the role of a variety of topological and pore chemical features of MOFs for the enhancement of CO2 capture. The CO2 capture capacity of the parent MOFs is often improved via functionalization with amino, nitro, hydroxyl, cyano-, or thiol-related chemistries but the efficacy depends strongly on the pore topology-related descriptors.125,126

Generally, MOFs beat zeolites in terms of the working capacities, energy consumptions, and efficiencies.113 Their performance can be further improved by post-synthetic modification,127 functionalization of organic linkers,128–130 and doping nanomaterials117,131 into their frameworks.132,133 A stronger CO2 molecule interaction with MOF was achieved by post-synthetic rapid heat treatment, giving rise to drastically improved adsorption performance. The temperature-activated transport confirmed the lattice stiffening.134 The introduction of a tertiary amine linker yields a higher affinity for CO2, leading to increased overall CO2 adsorption capacity.129 Less polar or non-polar solvents have more benefits than more polar ones towards alkylamine incorporation into MOFs. Alkylamine molecules dispersed in less polar solvents possess higher chemical potential, driving more alkylamine molecules to be integrated into the framework so as to form modified MOFs with drastically improved CO2 capture properties.85 The immobilization of unsaturated alkali metal sites in the MOFs via a tetrazole-based motif can greatly boost the gas affinity.135


2.2.4.1 Integration with functional components. The rational synergetic integration of multiple functional components such as combining ionic liquid with Lewis base sites and MOF with Lewis acid sites into a bifunctional composite material polyILs@MIL-101 could lead to significantly improved activity towards CO2 capture. The significantly enhanced activity of polyILs@MIL-101 is ascribed to the synergy effect among the Lewis base sites in the polyILs, Lewis acid sites in the MOF, and the good CO2 enrichment capacity.136 MOFs offer various chemical environments, resulting in different and complex structure-adsorbate chemical interactions towards CO2 separation. A novel bi-porous MOF, SION-8, endowed with chemically distinct hydrophobic and hydrophilic structural pores, was obtained by judiciously altered activation conditions. The intrinsic structural flexibility, primarily along the b-axis, correlated with the structural adjustments, which allowed for the accommodation of gas molecules and guest solvent (Fig. 18).137 In particular, isoreticular synthesis via the fine-tuning of inorganic moieties remains a great challenge.138 Jiang and co-workers successfully adjusted the channels in NJU-Bai35, achieving significantly high CO2 uptake (7.2%) by upgrading the inorganic clusters’ symmetry in isoreticular MOFs as well as the CO2 selectivity.139
Fig. 18 (a) A chain of alternating Ca–O atoms running along [100]. (b) Arrangement of the TBAPy4− ligands relative to the Ca–O chains. (c) A dihedral angle between the planes of the TBAPy4− ligands bound to two subsequent Ca atoms of 80.06°. (d) Tubular structural voids extending along the [100] direction, marked as gold surfaces, occupying 24.8% of the unit-cell volume (Reproduced from ref. 137 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018).

2.2.4.2 Intrinsic property regulation. The uniqueness of MOFs is that the intrinsic functionalities and properties could be finely regulated to address diverse applications. In particular, the co-existence of CO2 and H2S in natural gas and biogas causes severe corrosion problems for pipeline transportation and influences the quality standards in a variety of energy-related applications.140 The formation of impurities such as COS should be carefully avoided by selectively manipulating the concentration of CO2 and H2S. The high degree regulation of MOFs shows attractive potential in the selective removal of H2S and CO2 with different efficiencies. Through the integration of favorable sites for CO2 and H2S capture, Belmabkhout et al.141 reported the distinctive structural features offered by a fluorinated AlFFIVE-1-Ni, allowing the simultaneous removal of H2S and CO2. Interestingly, N-rich organic linkers are superior for the design of functional MOFs for CO2 and H2S separation due to their high affinity.142
2.2.4.3 Summary and outlook of MOF-based adsorbents. The thermal stability of MOF, particularly, their stability towards moisture, is a primary consideration for practical utilization.143 Developing MOFs with water-resistant features is a big challenge for practical CO2 capture. The hydroxo-functional groups are of paramount importance for enhancing the CO2 capture performance under humid conditions.144 The μ3-O groups interact strongly with the adsorbed H2O inside the pores due to the strong polarity of water molecules, which allows more CO2 to be efficiently trapped due to the confinement effect.144 González and co-workers reported an environment-friendly Mg(II)-based MOF, which exhibited high storage capabilities to reversibly adsorb H2S and CO2 with an unusual thermal stability (>500 °C).145

For the evaluation of the possibility of deploying MOFs towards CO2 separation in large-scale implementation, further pilot adsorption installations and investigations of functionalized compounds at the bench-scale are highly necessary. In 2018, Olajire published a systematic review on the synthetic chemistry of MOF for CO2 capture and conversion towards future sustainable energy development.132 Ghanbari and co-workers discussed the CO2 adsorption properties of MOFs, with an emphasis on the MOF structure design and adsorption mechanism in another review in 2020.146 The research interests on MOF-based CO2 adsorbents are briefly presented in Fig. 19. The introduction of Zn–OH groups with stronger nucleophilic properties could provide MOFs with enhanced CO2 uptake under low pressure. Functionalized mesoporous polymer supports play a critical role in the effective regulation of the crystal growth of MOFs on a localized surface, while the enhancement in the intimate interaction gives rise to synergistic properties. Unsaturated alkaline metal ions embedded into MOFs have proven to be another relatively straightforward method for boosting their CO2 affinity and the corresponding adsorption performance. The introduction of functional groups (tertiary amides or amines) to tune the inherent moisture adsorption properties of the MOFs could further improve the CO2 capture performance.129,147 Surface coating with polydimethylsiloxane dramatically enhances the moisture stability, which proves to be a facile methodology for stabilizing moisture-unstable MOFs with desirable CO2 capture capabilities under humid flue gas conditions.148 The use of MOF-based adsorbents also faces several challenges, for instance, low mechanical and thermal stabilities as well as poor moisture resistance under harsh conditions. Therefore, the development of functionalized MOFs with high mechanical and thermal stabilities is of vital importance, which needs further attention and in-depth studies.146 In addition, the cost of MOF-based adsorbents has to be significantly reduced to achieve further large-scale application.


Fig. 19 A brief summary of the research activities on MOF-based CO2 adsorbents123,126,128,135,144,146,149 (Reproduced from ref. 149 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 126 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 144 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 123 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 146 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2020; reproduced from ref. 135 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2019).
2.2.5 Alkali carbonate-based adsorbents. Alkali-metal carbonate-based adsorbents (mainly K2CO3 and Na2CO3) have been widely investigated for CO2 capture due to their high uptake, low cost, and low working temperatures (adsorption at 50–80 °C and desorption at <200 °C), which show great potential in application for fossil fuel power plants. Alkali metal carbonates can react with CO2 to form alkali metal hydrogen carbonate and the basic principle for CO2 adsorption is presented as follows:
 
M2CO3(s) + H2O(g) + CO2(g) ⇔ 2MHCO3(s)(3)
where M is potassium or sodium. The regeneration of Na2CO3/K2CO3 normally occurs at temperatures over 150 °C, which demands much energy during the process. Besides, there are some other problems including slow carbonation reaction rate and poor durability with the unmodified Na2CO3/K2CO3 adsorbents, thus restricting their industrial applications. Therefore, alkali-metal carbonates are always dispersed on stable and porous supports such as metal oxides (Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, MgO), active carbon, and zeolites to improve their performance. Al2O3-supported Na2CO3 adsorbent showed good CO2 adsorption at relatively low temperatures. With the addition of MgO, both the CO2 adsorption capacity and the adsorption rate could be increased compared to that of the Na2CO3/Al2O3 adsorbent.

In terms of both the CO2 adsorption capacity and the adsorption kinetics, K2CO3 generally performs better than Na2CO3. The adsorption process of K2CO3 as a CO2 adsorbent is divided into three steps: (i) the formation of K2CO3·1.5H2O, (ii) the transformation into K4H2(CO3)3·1.5H2O, and (iii) the further slow conversion into KHCO3. In particular, K2CO3/Al2O3 with high porosity and high mechanical strength is an ideal adsorbent for CO2 capture. The pathway of the Na2CO3 carbonation process was proposed by Cai and co-workers (Fig. 20),150 which is controlled by diffusion limitation rather than the reaction kinetics on the surface. One of the possible rate-limiting reaction pathways related to the diffusion of the reactants is that the CO2 and H2O molecules diffuse through the NaHCO3 layer and react at the interface of NaHCO3 and Na2CO3. Another possible reaction pathway is due to the Na+ diffusion from Na2CO3 and H+ counter diffusion from NaHCO3 to their interface, thus promoting the reaction.


Fig. 20 (a) Scheme of the Na2CO3 carbonation reaction with surface carbonation and diffusion-control and (b and c) two kinds of possible pathways for Na2CO3 carbonation (Reproduced from ref. 150 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2019).
2.2.6 Implementation and challenges in post-combustion applications. Despite the consensus that CCS could make a great difference in achieving the 2 °C target proposed by IPCC, the implementation of commercial-scale CCS projects has made slow progress. In 2019, there were fifty-one large-scale CCS facilities globally, with nineteen at work, four under construction, and the remainder under various stages of development.151 According to the classification of the nine-point TRL system, among all CO2 capture technologies, only the chemical absorption using amine solutions technology has reached a commercial scale (TRL 9). Adsorption-based processes, which are discussed in this section and in Section 2.4.4, are still at the demonstration stage (TRL 7).152

Post-combustion processes separate CO2 from the flue gas released by fossil fuel combustion in power plants or industrial processes including coking, iron, and steel as well as cement and oil refining. Post-combustion CO2 capture operates at atmospheric pressures and low temperatures (<200 °C) with CO2 concentrations varying from 5% to 20%, which depend on the carbon sources. The impurities in the flue gases (NOx, SOx, solid particles) are removed before passing through the CO2 capture facilities. Since first being considered in the 1990s,153 adsorption processes for post-combustion CO2 capture have undergone rapid development as a substitute for the chemical absorption processes due to their avoidance of the hydrodynamics, volatility, and degradation problems associated with the use of chemisorption solvents. Research efforts towards post-combustion CO2 capture based on adsorption technologies have been directed at three aspects: (1) low-temperature adsorbents with larger CO2 working capacities, faster kinetics, higher selectivity, and better stability; (2) efficient cyclic processes with energy-saving regeneration methods; and (3) novel adsorbent structures and capture devices with low gas-solid mass transfer resistance.

VPSA or VSA is regarded as a relatively mature technology for post-combustion CO2 capture, which is based on physisorbents such as zeolites or activated carbon with pressurized feed gas.154–157 The regeneration pressure for a single VSA unit packed with zeolite 13X should be lower than 10 kPa to obtain a CP of 95%. Although the use of novel adsorbents, such as MOFs, to reduce the vacuum requirements is possible, these adsorbents are not currently available in large amounts. Therefore, VSA systems commonly adopt multi-stage configurations, allowing flexible adsorbent packing and process sequencing. Dry flue gas is commonly required in a VSA system to avoid the performance degradation of physisorbents, which causes additional capture cost. The energy consumption of the VSA process is between 1.5 and 3 MJe kg−1, which is equal to 4.5–9 MJth kg−1.

TSA is a more attractive option for the separation of CO2 from dilute gases. One obvious advantage of the TSA process based on chemisorbents is avoiding the requirement of pre-drying the flue gas, which accounts for 2–3 MJth kg−1 of additional energy consumption. In the TSA process, it is preferable to implement low-pressure steam for regeneration. This requires the adsorbents to be water-tolerant. A fluidized bed configuration is commonly adopted in TSA to enhance the heat transfer during heating and cooling.158–160

In early 2014, the Korea Institute of Energy Research installed the largest adsorbent-based post-combustion CO2 capture demonstration system, the 10 MWe-scale KIERDARY® plant, which is fed with 35000 N m3 h−1 flue gas from the Hadong coal-fired power plant and has the ability to capture 200 t CO2 d−1.158 The pilot plant used a two fluidized bed configuration, where the sorbent KEP-CO2P2 (K2CO3-based sorbent) captures and releases CO2 at 40–80 °C and 140–200 °C, respectively. The simulation studies indicated that the energy consumption of the plant was required to reach an 80% CCR and 95% CP is 4–5 MJth kg−1. Furthermore, the ADAsorb process, with a three-stage fluidized bed reactor, was used to develop a 1 MWe post-combustion CO2 capture installation for a coal-fired electricity generation plant in Alabama, USA.161 In addition to power generation sources, RTI International developed a fluidized bed-based TSA process to trap CO2 from the Brevik cement plant via a polyamine-based solid adsorbent at operating temperatures of about 60–70 °C and 110–120 °C.159 The estimated cost for RTI's TSA is between 38 and 46 € t−1.

The moving bed avoids the use of multiple reactors for the fixed bed system in a large-scale plant and is thus regarded as another candidate for TSA separation applications.162–164 The KCC system is a typical post-combustion CO2 capture pilot plant based on the moving bed reactor.162 The solid sorbent, a polyamine-impregnated mesocellular silica foam provided by the Research Institute of Innovative Technology for the Earth, flows into the top of the reactor and passes successively through the absorption, regeneration, and adsorbent dryer zones before being collected at the bottom using a circulating conveyer. The bench-test plant captures 5.5 t CO2 d−1 from the flue gas containing 13% CO2, and waste heat is used to generate steam (60 °C) for regeneration. The next plan for the Kawasaki system is to scale up this technology to 40 t CO2 d−1. In another moving bed process, SRI, Linde, and ATMI developed an advanced carbon sorbent technique based on carbon beads for CO2 capture from a 0.5 MWe slipstream of a coal-fired electricity generation plant.164 The estimated capture cost of SRI's ACS is $45 t−1 CO2. TDA Research, Inc., is also planning to build a 0.5 MWe-scale post-combustion CO2 capture demonstration system with a simulated moving bed process using alkalized alumina.163

One of the main challenges of the moving bed process arises from the low gas velocity that is required to avoid the fluidization of the adsorbents, which leads to intolerantly large equipment dimensions. The use of structured sorbents can solve this problem. An example is the VeloxoTherm™ process developed by Svante Inc., in Canada,165 which consists of a rotary adsorption unit divided by three gas paths for flue gas (adsorption), steam (regeneration), and air cooling. This technology uses structured silica gel functionalized with amine, which allows a fast adsorption–desorption process in 60 s with almost no pressure drop and high mass and heat transfer. It was reported that Svante launched a demonstration plant capturing 30 t CO2 d−1 from a natural gas steam boiler in Saskatchewan and will build a facility of the same size with funding by Chevron Technology Ventures.

Post-combustion CO2 capture technologies based on adsorbents offer alternatives to amine-based absorption processes but their further development is needed to reach higher TRLs. Table 1 summarizes the current status of adsorption-based post-combustion CO2 capture facilities. High-throughput simulation is required to evaluate the large number of adsorbent candidates to meet the multi-objective optimization of the adsorption performance (e.g., CO2 uptake, kinetics, selectivity, and stability) and the process performance (e.g., CCR, CP, energy consumption, abd productivity).166 When the TSA process is used in post-combustion CO2 capture, the adsorption bed should be designed carefully to achieve better heat integration as well as a good balance between the gas–solid mass transfer and the pressure drop. A fully comprehensive comparison between the adsorption and absorption processes pertaining to energy consumption and operating cost is still lacking. In addition, more pilot-scale post-combustion CO2 capture facilities should be implemented to acquire engineering experience with adsorption technologies.

Table 1 Status of adsorption-based post-combustion CO2 capture facilities
Project Feed flow rate Adsorbent(s) Process Reactor CCR (%) CP (%) Energy Sources Country Ref.
Single-stage VPSA 46 N m3 h−1 (dehydrated) Zeolite 5A VPSA Fixed bed 79 85 2.37 MJe kg−1 Power generation China 154
Two-stage VPSA 35 N m3 h−1 (dehydrated) Zeolite 13X APG & activated carbon beads VPSA Fixed bed 90.2 95.6 2.44 MJe kg−1 Power generation China 155
DR-VPSA 100 N m3 h−1 (dehydrated) Activated carbon VPSA Fixed bed 44.6 87.5 3.52 MJe kg−1 Power generation Poland 156
ASCOA-3 330 N m3 h−1 Zeolite (zeolum F9) VSA Fixed bed 80 90 0.44 MJe kg−1 Steel Japan 157
TEPCO's two-stage VSA 1000 N m3 h−1 (dehydrated) Ca–X zeolite PTSA/VSA Fixed bed 90 99 2.02 MJe kg−1 Power generation Japan 153
KIERDARY 35000 N m3 h−1 K2CO3-based sorbent TSA Fluidized bed 80 95 4.0–5.0 MJth kg−1 Power generation Korea 158
ADAsorb 0.38 kg s−1 Amine-based ion exchange polymer TSA Three-staged fluidized bed 90 89.4 4.75 MJth kg−1 Power generation USA 161
RTI's TSA — PEI-based sorbent TSA Fluidized bed 90 2.4 MJth kg−1 Cement USA 159
KCC 1000 N m3 h−1 Amine-coated porous material VTSA Moving bed 75 95 1.3 MJe kg−1 Power generation Japan 162
SRI's ACS 120 m3 h−1 Carbon beads TSA Moving bed 67 93 — Power generation USA 164
TDA's SMB 0.63 kg s−1 Alkalized alumina TSA Simulated moving bed — — — Power generation USA 163
VeloxoTherm — Diamine-tethered silica gel RTSA Rotary wheel — 90 1.5 MJe kg−1 Power generation Canada 165

2.3. Intermediate-temperature solid CO2 adsorbents

Pre-combustion technologies have received tremendous attention for industrial hydrogen production due to their small-scale capturing system, low energy consumption, and high adsorption efficiency. Fossil fuels transform into CO2 and H2 through combustion, resulting in high gas pressure and CO2 concentration, which is favorable for CO2 capture. Syngas (CO + H2O) is converted into a gas mixture containing CO2 and H2 through the water gas shift reactor at 200–400 °C. The introduction of in situ CO2 adsorption materials could effectively achieve the integration of WGS and the gas separation process in one reactor. Layered double hydroxide (LDH)-derived mixed metal oxides (LDOs) and magnesium oxide (MgO) have excellent affinity for acidic CO2 molecules in the intermediate temperature range of 200–400 °C and thus possess good CO2 capturing potential for the SEWGS process.
2.3.1 LDH-based adsorbents. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) with precisely controlled chemical composition and tunable properties have been well studied in many fields (Fig. 21a).167 Though LDHs have been deployed as adsorbents for decades, their first application in CO2 capture appeared in 2001.168 The LDOs capture CO2 at intermediate-temperature (200–450 °C), and thus can be applied in the SEWGS reaction. The research of LDH on CO2 capture started with its tunable chemical composition,169 followed by the synthetic method, doping with alkali metals, LDH-based composite, and the influence of the other gases as well as the adsorption mechanism.
Fig. 21 (a) Schematic structure of the LDHs,167 (b) CO2 capture performance of different Mg3X–CO3 (X = Al, Fe, Ga, and Mn) LDHs as a function of the calcination temperature (Reproduced from ref. 170 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2010), (c) the diagram of the structural change in the Mg3Al–stearate LDH and Mg3Al–CO3 LDH after calcination at 400 °C, (d) the CO2 uptake of Mg3Al–stearate LDH and Mg3Al–CO3 LDH.171

2.3.1.1 The effect of chemical composition and fabrication method of LDHs. The CO2 capture performance of LDOs has been found to be highly dependent on the divalent and trivalent cations within the brucite-like layers and the interlayer anions. The influence of divalent cations including Mg2+, Co2+, Ca2+, and Cu2+ was studied by Wang et al.,169 where the Ca–Co–Al LDH system displayed the highest CO2 adsorption capacity (1.39 mmol g−1). Wang et al.170 revealed that the trivalent cations (Al3+, Fe3+, Mn3+, and Ga3+) can affect the dehydration and the dehydroxylation/decarbonation processes, and different LDHs (with different trivalent cations) possess different optimal calcination temperatures (Fig. 21b). Among them, MgAl LDH displayed the highest CO2 adsorption capacity and excellent thermal stability. Moreover, due to the good affinity of lithium-containing complex oxides with CO2, LiAl2 LDH, as a unique monovalent cation containing LDH for CO2 capture, was first reported by Huang et al.172 The basic Li–O and lattice O2− sites were formed after thermal treatment, which was beneficial for CO2 capture. In short, the trivalent cations in LDHs may influence the layer charge density, whereas the divalent cations in LDH can provide the basic sites and affect the optimal adsorption temperature.169,170,172

Different optimal divalent/trivalent ratios also depend on the type of interlayer anions. Therefore, the effect of interlay anions (CO32−, NO3−, Cl−, ClO4−, Fe(CN6)4−, SO42−, and HCO3−) in LDHs on the CO2 capture performance has also been investigated. Among them, Mg/Al–CO3 LDH exhibited the greatest advantages in the CO2 capture performance with the highest specific surface area.173 The anions in LDHs can affect its thermal stability, morphology, and SSA, thus affecting its CO2 capture ability. Based on the above results, Wang et al.171 first fabricated an organic anion stearate (C17H35COO−) intercalated LDH for CO2 capture. By replacing CO32− with long carbon-chained C17H35COO−, its CO2 uptake was significantly enhanced from 0.5 to 1.25 mmol g−1 (Fig. 21d). The structural changes in the Mg–Al–CO3 and Mg–Al–stearate LDHs are comparatively illustrated in Fig. 21c. Compared with CO32−, the decomposition of C17H35COO− could generate more surface basic sites. The obtained LDOs possess lower degree of crystallinity and more stable structures, which are beneficial for capturing CO2. Qin et al.174 further studied the influence of the carbon-chain length on the CO2 capture performance of organo-LDHs. The CO2 uptake increased significantly when the carbon chain increased from 10 to 16. Therefore, it was concluded that larger interlayer spacing, higher layer charge density, and greater number of basic sites are more favorable for capturing CO2 over LDOs.

Moreover, the synthetic method could result in LDHs with different morphologies including “stone-like”, “platelet-like”, and “sand rose” morphologies, consequently influencing the CO2 capture performance. Wang et al.175 employed the IEP theory to fabricate nano-sized spherical LDH for CO2 adsorption. The obtained LDHs showed mesoporous structures and large pores. The average particle size of the obtained LDHs was about 20 nm, which is favorable for the dispersion of alkali metals.


2.3.1.2 LDH-based composites. In recent years, LDH-based composites have become very promising as CO2 adsorbents. To enhance the adsorption ability and cycling stability of LDO adsorbents, different carbon materials (CNF, GO, and CNT) have been studied as supports for LDHs.176–178 In general, three synthetic methods are often employed, namely, direct co-precipitation, electrostatically driven self-assembly, and hydrothermal urea reaction. Garcia-Gallastegui et al.178,179 prepared LDH/MWCNT and LDH/GO composites by direct co-precipitation (Fig. 22a) and proved that the CO2 capture performance of the LDH were enhanced both in terms of the adsorption ability and cycling stability. The enhanced interactions between the gas and the adsorbent were attributed to the increased effective SSA and the disordered structure of the composites. By utilizing the electrostatically driven self-assembly process, Wang et al.180 prepared highly dispersed LDH/GO composites from two exfoliated LDH and GO solutions (Fig. 22b). The obtained LDH/GO composite with 6.54 wt% GO resulted in maximum CO2 uptake, which was two times higher than that of pure LDH without GO due to the dispersion of exfoliated LDH and the stabilization caused by GO. Qiao et al.181 fabricated multilayer LDH/MgCO3 hybrids on aluminum foil/mesh using the urea hydrolysis method (Fig. 22c). The aluminum foil/mesh, which functioned as a substrate and the sole source of aluminum, could effectively prevent the sintering and pasting problems. More importantly, the Al-supported LDH thin film can be further made into any shape for practical applications.
Fig. 22 (a) The schematic structure of the LDH/GO composite synthesized by the direct co-precipitation method,179 (b) the photographs of the electrostatically driven self-assembly process of exfoliated LDH and GO (Reproduced from ref. 180 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2015), (c) the synthetic diagram of the LDH/MgCO3 hybrids.181

2.3.1.3 Doping with alkali metals. Doping alkali metal carbonates on LDH is another effective method to promote its CO2 capture performance.182 Numerous studies have been focused on the use of K2CO3 as a promoter since K2CO3 impregnation can increase the amount of active sites on LDH, thus enhancing the adsorption capacity, thermal stability, and cycling stability of the parent LDH. The level of adsorption depends on the doping amount of K2CO3 on the LDH. 10–30 wt% of K2CO3 was proved to be the optimum loading amount, considering that the overload of K2CO3 may block the pores of LDH. Wang et al.173 found that organic solvents may result in better dispersion of K2CO3 than inorganic solvents during K impregnation, thus enhancing the promotion of CO2 capture capacity. Long carbon chains as anions can enlarge the interlayer distance for promoting more cation exchange on the external surface or the internal surface of each of its layers. Therefore, the K2CO3-promoted stearate-pillared LDH exhibited a superior CO2 uptake of 1.93 mmol g−1 at 300 °C, which is much higher than that of K2CO3-promoted carbonate intercalated LDHs (1.11 mmol g−1). Likewise, Meis et al.176 compared the CO2 adsorption performance of supported LDHs and unsupported LDH with K2CO3 doping and found that K2CO3 loaded on the supported LDH showed higher adsorption capacity than that of the unsupported LDH due to the existence of K+ on the surface of the supported LDH after thermal treatment, which caused a higher concentration of defects on the K2CO3-loaded supported LDHs (Fig. 23). The higher occurrence of low-coordinated sites (corners and edges) was considered to be of significant importance for CO2 capture. Therefore, K2CO3 was further used to improve the CO2 uptake of the LDH-based composite adsorbents by Wang and Zhu et al.177,180,183
Fig. 23 The schematic representation of the addition of K2CO3 to supported/unsupported LDHs (the red ball represents oxygen, the light gray ball represents magnesium, and the dark gray ball represents potassium) (Reproduced from ref. 176 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2010).

Commercially available LDHs commonly exhibit stone-like morphologies with highly stacked structures, which lead to low SSA for doping alkali metal ions. Though it is reported that LDH layers are possible to be exfoliated into nanosheets through “top down” or “bottom up” methods,184 they are easy to re-stack during the drying process due to their high surface charges and hydrophilic properties. Recently, O’Hare's group successfully synthesized a series of Zn2Al–borate LDH nanosheets with high SSA (459 m2 g−1) and large pore volumes (2.15 cm3 g−1) using a facile exfoliation method called AMOST.185 AMOST refers to the washing of the LDH wet cake with AMO solvents in the co-precipitation process; thus, the interlayer water is removed. The replaced AMO solvent molecules are then evaporated during the following drying process, which makes the LDH layers easy to slide. Zhu et al.186 reported flower-like Mg3Al–CO3 LDH after acetone washing, which leads to more uniform dispersion of the impregnated K+ ions, exhibiting increased CO2 uptake by about 22.9% at 400 °C compared to that of commercial K-MG70 (Fig. 24). A subsequent work screened six impregnation solvents and proved that ethanediol is more effective for dispersing the doped K2CO3 than water on the surface of the LDH prepared by the AMOST method.187


Fig. 24 Scheme of AMOST and the characterization of K-promoted LDH before and after acetone washing (Reproduced from ref. 186 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2019).

In addition to alkali metal carbonates, alkali metal nitrates have also been studied as promoters for LDH-based adsorbents. For instance, the CO2 uptake of LDH with a Mg/Al molar ratio of 20 can reach a relatively high value of 9.27 mmol g−1 with the existence of NaNO3 at 240 °C.182 Qin et al.174 verified that ternary alkali nitrates (Li–Na–K)NO3 can also enhance the CO2 capture performance of a carboxylic anion-intercalated LDH. Lara-García et al.188 investigated the mechanism of (Li–Na–K)NO3 promoted Mg–Al–palmitate LDH by in situ DRIFTS and confirmed that two reaction processes took place for nitrates for enhancing the CO2 adsorption ability. In the first process, CO2 combined with the melted NO3−, resulting in the generation of NO2− and CO32−. Then, the CO32− reacted with the calcined LDH material to form MgCO3. In the second process, O2− was released and reacted with nitrite, thus recovering the initial NO3− species.


2.3.1.4 Adsorption mechanism. LDH itself does not have alkaline sites, while its derived metal oxides after thermal treatment contain abundant alkaline sites. According to the CO2 adsorption mechanism over LDH-derived adsorbents, the Mg–O species are the active sites for CO2 capture.169,189 Gao et al.190 proposed two possible active Mg–O species formation mechanisms for LDH. The Mg–O species were achieved by replacing Mg2+ with Al3+ at the octahedral positions in the MgO lattice, resulting in Mg vacancies, or by the diffusion of Al3+ out of the octahedral brucite layers, leaving behind Al vacancies. Recently, Zhu et al.191 applied in situ techniques to illustrate the CO2 adsorption mechanism of K-promoted MgxAl–CO3 LDH with different Mg/Al ratios. They proved that there is a synergistic effect between the K+ ions and the Mg/Al ratio. After adsorbing CO2, bidentate carbonates are formed on the surface of the K-promoted LDH. However, when the Mg/Al ratio is less than two, unidentate carbonates with stronger binding force are also formed. In practice, the actual mechanism of CO2 adsorption and desorption on LDHs is complex.
2.3.1.5 Summary and outlook of LDH-based adsorbents. To the best of our knowledge, for intermediate-temperature CO2 capture, there are only two promising adsorbent candidates so far, namely, LDH and MgO. MgO has attracted a great interest in recent years due to the extraordinary progress achieved by doping molten salts. However, Zhu et al.192 found that K2CO3-promoted MgO showed lower CO2 uptake with trace CO2, whereas K2CO3-promoted LDH exhibited higher uptake with relatively low Mg/Al ratio under the same conditions. They proposed that the introduction of Al3+ to Mg2+ combined with K2CO3 may create more CO2 adsorption sites. Meanwhile, unidentate carbonates were formed in K2CO3-promoted LDH with the lowest Mg/Al ratio, making it possible to capture extremely low concentration CO2.

The service life of the adsorbents has significant economic implications on any commercial-scale operations. The introduction of carbon materials as supports can help to minimize the pulverization of LDH. However, there are few studies that have reported the uses of LDH-based composites for long-time cycling tests. Although doping alkali metals can enhance the CO2 capture capacity of LDH-derived CO2 adsorbents, the relatively low adsorption capacity and poor cycling stability are still a challenge. The adsorption mechanism and the alkali metal promotion mechanism for CO2 adsorption over LDH-derived adsorbents are still controversial, which need more in-depth investigations. It was suggested that the molecular models and force fields should be developed to investigate the adsorption mechanism of LDH-derived CO2 adsorbents based on the actual flue gas conditions. LDH-derived CO2 adsorbents have displayed significant advantages in the adsorption of low concentration CO2 but the intrinsic reason remains unclear. In addition, the influence of the impurities in the flue gas, including H2O, SO2, and H2S, on the CO2 uptake of LDH needs to be further investigated. Finally, parameters relevant to cost analysis, lifetime of the adsorbent, and kinetics under the industrial operating conditions should also be taken into account.

2.3.2 MgO-based adsorbents. Magnesium oxide (MgO), which is abundant on Earth, exhibits promising potential for CO2 capture due to its high theoretical adsorption capability, lack of toxicity, low cost, and relatively low regeneration temperature.193,194 It can capture CO2 in the temperature range of 200–400 °C and can be easily regenerated at a moderate temperature at 450 °C.195 However, the main obstacle in MgO adsorbents towards the practical application of CO2 capture lies in its low actual CO2 uptake and poor adsorption kinetics due to the intrinsically high lattice enthalpy and barren basic active sites.196 It is commonly accepted that MgO displays reduced uptake tendency during high-temperature exposure in CO2 capture, resulting from the decline in SSA due to sintering.193 The low-coordination Mg2+–O2− sites located at the corner/edge exhibit favorable interaction towards CO2, resulting in inherently limited adsorption performance. Recently, the “negative-sintering” hypothesis was challenged by Mutch and co-workers using both spectroscopic and computational methods, who first claimed necessary high-temperature conditions for facet-dependent surface activation to unleash the capability of the MgO polar (111) facet.197
2.3.2.1 Fabrication with mesoporous structure. Mesoporous materials as heterogeneous adsorbents, which possess narrow pore size distributions, provide a combination of a certain degree of shape- as well as size- selectivity and large SSAs. Therefore, Gao and co-workers fabricated mesoporous MgO adsorbents possessing abundant basic sites, which exhibited a superior CO2 capture capacity of 2 mmol g−1. During the interaction with CO2, a variety of carbonate surface species including monodentate and bidentate carbonates as well as bicarbonate were generated on the surface of MgO.193 Using small-sized MgO with more corner- and edge-located basic O2− capturing active sites in the O2−–Mg2+ bonds for acidic CO2 molecule could achieve higher capturing efficiency for MgO. Meanwhile, combination with a support can further enhance the regenerability of the MgO species, thus preventing its agglomeration over multiple cycles.198 Inspired by this, Li's group dispersed ultrafine MgO nanocrystallites with full exposure of the active sites on well-defined dual supports (amorphous C and rGO sheets as protectants). The novel hierarchical rGO@MgO/C nanocomposite system possessing unique physicochemical properties (large SSA, sheet-on-sheet architecture, and abundant nanopores) exhibits remarkable CO2 uptake (1.36 mmol g−1), fast adsorption kinetics, as well as superior process durability.199
2.3.2.2 Molten salts modification. Notably, Gao and co-workers published a review in 2017, which summarized the fabrication and property advances of molten salt-modified MgO-based CO2 adsorbents, which has emerged as a promising approach to enhance the capturing performance of MgO adsorbents.200,201 The CO2 uptake for pure MgO is far from satisfactory, even with the optimization by the above-mentioned promotion methods (<2 mmol g−1). In 2015, Harada and coworkers reported the remarkable effect of molten salts on the CO2 uptake of highly regenerable MgO (>10.2 mmol g−1) at ∼300 °C. The generation of a CO2-impermeable monodentate carbonate rigid layer on the MgO surface is effectively prevented by the molten salts and CO2 capture capability with a high rate is promoted by the rapid generation of carbonate ions (Fig. 25).202,203 Inspired by the promotion effect of the molten salts, Qiao and co-workers further improved the CO2 uptake of MgO to 16 mmol g−1 by optimizing the alkali metal ratio (Li/Na/K) of the nitrates.204 In 2018, Zhao's group fabricated NaNO3/NaNO2 mixture-promoted mesoporous MgO, which exhibited a superior CO2 uptake of 19.8 mmol g−1 at 350 °C.205 The significant improvement achieved by the introduction of molten salts for MgO-based adsorbents makes it a research hot topic for SEWGS. However, the detailed reaction mechanism for molten salt-promoted MgO is not yet fully understood.205,206
Fig. 25 Schematic illustration of the possible reaction occurring in the molten alkali metal nitrate-coated MgO (Reproduced from ref. 202 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2015).

The durability of molten salt-promoted MgO adsorbents during multiple sorption-regeneration cycles has become a major concern for their real applications in SEWGS. Trivino and co-workers utilized commercially available LDHs as stabilizers to improve the cyclic stability of NaNO3-promoted MgO adsorbents. Restricting the formation of non-uniform and large product crystallites, the LDHs effectively act as templates for MgCO3 and regulate the basic sites for their high interaction with both NaNO3 and MgO (Fig. 26).198 In 2019, the same group went a step further to apply this novel MgO-based adsorbent to the SEWGS process for 30 cycles. The superior CO2 capture performance resulted in greatly increased H2 purity (99.4% in dry basis) at 300 °C, 12 atm in the 1st cycle, which remained stable over ten consecutive cycles, thus indicating its excellent regenerability (Fig. 27).207


Fig. 26 Formation of smaller MgCO3 crystals, exposure of stabilized sites, and higher MgO-stablizer-NaNO3 interactions (Reproduced from ref. 198 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2018).

Fig. 27 Sorption-enhanced water gas shift reaction by in situ CO2 capture on an alkali metal salt-promoted MgO–CaCO3 adsorbent (Reproduced from ref. 207 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2019).

2.3.2.3 Summary and outlook of MgO-based adsorbents. Overall, the research strategies for improving the CO2 adsorption properties of MgO-based adsorbents are briefly summarized in Fig. 28. A timely review covering deeper and broader advancements of MgO adsorbents has been provided by Hu and co-workers in 2019.196 However, the development of MgO adsorbent granulation techniques and the enhancement of granule performance are quite urgent for realistic large-scale applications with excellent mechanical and chemical properties.208 The ease of granulation operation and energy consumption of the manufacturing process should be taken into consideration for industrial implementation. Future tests need to be focused on the evaluation of the adsorption performance under realistic conditions and targeted apparatus to verify the techno-economic consumption of MgO-based CO2 adsorbents for implementation.
Fig. 28 A brief summary of the research activities on MgO-based CO2 adsorbents (Reproduced from ref. 208 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2019; reproduced from ref. 193 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 200 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2017).

2.4. High-temperature solid CO2 sorbents

Methane-reforming is a highly efficient, economical, and widely used process for industrial H2 production at high temperatures (600–900 °C). The sorption enhanced methane-reforming (SEMR) process requires high-temperature solid CO2 sorbents such as calcium oxide, alkali silicate, and alkali titanate, which can effectively capture CO2 in the relatively high temperature range of 600–900 °C. The deployment of such sorbents could successfully inhibit large heat consumption, simplify the whole process, and further improve the conversion efficiency of CH4 to form H2 with simultaneously captured CO2 of high purity.
2.4.1 CaO-based sorbents.
2.4.1.1 Basic principle of CaO-based adsorbents. Calcium oxide (CaO)-based materials have been widely studied as high temperature CO2 sorbents since 1933.209 Owing to its high theoretical sorption capacity and availability, CaO has shown great potential applications in CO2 capture. With decades of research, more and more CaO-based CO2 sorbents with high-performance have been reported, driving this research forward from the foundation towards real applications. For practical applications, the sorption capacity is one of the dominating parameters for determining the cost and efficiency. However, the sorption capacity of CaO is poisoned by the CaCO3 layer formed outside the CaO sorbent. Since CaCO3 formation is inevitable, the capacity for CO2 sorption on CaO, which is highly dependent on the particle size, decreases rapidly due to the sintering of the sorbent particles over multiple cycles. A widely accepted explanation suggests that it is the low Tammann temperature of CaCO3 (533 °C) that leads to sintering.210 The powder sorbents need to be treated before implementation as the CaO powder in the reactor is prone to pressure drop and elutriation. In order to solve the above problems, several efforts have been devoted to the following areas over the last three years, including (1) CO2 uptake enhancement, (2) sintering-resistance improvement, (3) powder granulation, and (4) practical application exploration.
2.4.1.2 Enhancement of CO2 capture performance. To enhance the CO2 sorption capacity of CaO, a large amount of work has been carried out on particle size reduction, SSA increment, and surface modification. A variety of methods, such as hydration, acid treatment, precursor selection, physical grinding, and preparation process control, have been studied thoroughly in the early stages. On top of that, there has been a lot of original work in the last three years, which is especially focused on precursor modification and doping. Zhao et al.211 proposed a surfactant-free method to prepare morphology-controlled CaCO3 precursors by the reaction of Ca(NO3)2 with the CO2 storage material (CO2 bubbled ethylenediamine + ethylene glycol) and obtained nano CaO by roasting the CaCO3 precursors. The synthetic CaO particle size is about 480 nm × 255 nm, which facilitates a high sorption capacity (17.18 mmol g−1, 92% of the theoretical sorption capacity). Besides CaCO3, Ca(OH)2 is also commonly used as a CaO precursor.

Apart from the above-mentioned progress, doping with an addition agent is also an effective way to improve the sorption performance. Among all the additives, the most representative additives are metal oxides. Though metal oxides are often used to enhance the stability, they can be utilized to improve the sorption performance of CaO. In terms of energy, Liu et al.212 explored the effect of metal additives on the reactivity of CaO carbonation by DFT, indicating that the sorption energy on various promoted CaO surfaces followed the order Zr > Al > Mg > Na. The higher sorption energy demonstrated that the addition of this substance facilitates the carbonation of CaO. The CaO carbonation process involves CO2 chemisorption, surface reaction with O2− to form CO32−, and finally, the generation of CaCO3.

The diffusion of CO2 and mobility of O2− are key factors for CO2 capture. Based on these, Guo et al.213 reported a (Zr–Ce)-additive with facilitated CO2 capture of the CaO-based sorbent. Due to the formation of Ce2Zr2O7, oxygen vacancies were created to facilitate the diffusion of CO2 and O2− mobility. Similarly, Huang et al.214 developed a low melting point oxy-salt eutectic doped CaO. By loading CaO with alkali carbonate molten salt, its CO2 uptake could be significantly improved from 3.26 to 10.94 mmol g−1 at the first carbonation process (Fig. 29a), which can be ascribed to the high O2− concentration and O2− conductivity of the molten salt (Fig. 29b).215


Fig. 29 (a) CO2 sorption/desorption cycling performance of CaO and molten salt-promoted CaO, (b) schematic diagrams of the reaction with CO2 for low melting point oxy-salt eutectic coated CaO particle214,215 (Reproduced from ref. 214 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2017).

2.4.1.3 Improvement in sintering-resistance. Capacity loss is recognized as the most serious problem for CaO-based sorbents. In this regard, extensive work has been devoted to preventing the sintering effect and to improving the cyclic stability. One of the most feasible options is to incorporate CaO particles with inert materials. In earlier studies, supporting materials including Al2O3, MgO, Y2O3, CuO, CeO2, TiO2, KMnO4, SiO2, CexZryOz, La2O3, LaAlxMgyO3, and CaZrO3 have been thoroughly investigated and reviewed but the state-of-the-art works still need to be highlighted to reveal some new trends. Based on previous research, the study of CaO-based materials lays more emphasis on the performance and economy. Additives such as Al2O3, MgO, ZrO2, and their mixtures are preferred due to the high stability of their derivatives such as Ca12Al14O33, Ca9Al6O18, MgAl2O4, and CaZrO3. For stabilized CaO sorbents, the dispersion degree of inert supports is a determining factor for sintering resistance. Hence, the research emphasis aims to achieve a good dispersion of the supporting materials in the calcium precursor or CaO by adapting various synthetic methods, such as coprecipitation, sol–gel, hydrothermal, milling, spray/freeze drying, and flame spray pyrolysis. Different precursors prepared by the aforementioned methods allow to obtain stabilized CaO with specific morphology, structure, and mixing degree. Furthermore, Armutlulu et al.216 published an ALD strategy to prepare shell-comprising nanoparticles with Al2O3 film on the CaO nanoparticles. By wrapping hollow CaO in the thin Al2O3 layer (<3 nm), the sintering between the particles was effectively prevented (Fig. 30a). For CaO with 10 ALD cycles, CO2 uptake of 55 wt% was achieved after 30 cycles (80.5% capacity retention), which is higher than that of untreated synthesized CaO (40 wt% with 53.4% capacity retention); both the samples exhibited far more superior uptake compared to the performance of limestone (11 wt% with about 20.3% capacity retention). The high cyclic stability of Al2O3-stabilized CaO was attributed to its favorable morphological characteristics and the hollow spherical structure was extensively preserved during the cyclic operation (Fig. 30b). Calcium precursor was suggested to show an effect on the morphology and structure of CaO, especially the porous structure generated by the calcination of the organic precursor. Therefore, organic calcium has been selected as the CaO precursor in many mixing methods, for instance, calcium acetate. Huang et al.217 employed a facile solvent/non-solvent method to prepare MgO/CaO using calcium acetate as the precursor. The MgO/CaO composite was obtained at a nano-meter mixing level (Fig. 31), exhibiting a CO2 uptake of 59.2 wt% after 7 cycles (with 95.3% retention of its initial capacity).
Fig. 30 (a) HR-TEM of ALD-grown Al2O3 coating CaO nanoparticles with EDX mapping; (b) SEM of Al2O3-stabilized CaO sorbents before and after carbonation over 30 cycles (Reproduced from ref. 216 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2017).

Fig. 31 SEM images of CaO and MgO/CaO prepared by solvent/non-solvent before and after 10 cycles (a) CaO, (b) MgO/CaO, (c) CaO after 10 cycles, and (d) MgO/CaO after 10 cycles, and (e) the schematic illustration of the possible mechanism of stability enhancement (Reproduced from ref. 217 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2018).

2.4.1.4 CaO derived from waste resources. Though the synthetic stabilized CaO shows higher CO2 uptake and better stability, the high cost still inhibits its further practical application. From economic perspectives, the deployment of solid waste or minerals as calcium precursors or inert additives is being more widely applied. Common cheap calcium sources are limestone, dolomite, eggshell, seashell, and metallurgical slag. The materials used as additives such as bauxite tailings, sepiolite, fruit bunch, ash, and cement generally contain Al, Si, and Mg. The use of these cheap raw materials/scrap can not only reduce the production cost of the sorbent but also render the management of solid waste with great practical value. Unlike the direct synthesis of stabilized CaO with chemical reagents, the extraction of the calcium source and dopant is required before the sorbent preparation. Generally, the calcium sources and dopant precursors are mechanically crushed, dried, and then mixed.
2.4.1.5 Powder granulation. The above studies are mainly focused on the preparation and characterization of CaO sorbents in the powder form. For implementation, powders cannot be applied directly due to the elutriation from the carbonator and the regenerator. To fix the CaO sorbents, granulation and coating methods are executed to prepare molding materials. However, low CaO loading greatly reduces the sorption capacity. Another strategy is to prepare molding CaO by granulation, for example, extrusion-spheronization, to make CaO into pellets by mechanical forces. However, this methodology inevitably causes the destruction of the porous microstructures of the powder materials.218 To improve the CO2 uptake of CaO-based pellets, pore-forming templates were widely used to enhance the porosity, such as cellulose,219 hemicellulose,220 plastic wastes,218 lignin,220 and urea.221 Among these, the most widely used template is cellulose. Li et al.219 modified CaO pellets with 30% microcrystalline cellulose and found that the CO2 uptake (34 wt%) was increased by 48% compared to that of the unmodified pellets after 20 cycles. They attributed this enhancement to the gas channels and cavity formation caused by gas release and the disappearance of microcrystalline cellulose during the burning of the porosity promoter.

With the gradual improvement of CaO properties and reduction in the production costs by the deployment of cheap precursors, more studies have been focused on the application of CO2 adsorption by CaO, viz., CaL. CaL was initially studied in the power sector as an alternative to amine scrubbing for post-combustion capture to reduce the costs or was used for pre-combustion in IGCC, and had already been tested in bench- and pilot-scale plants. A comprehensive review paper on pilot-plant testing of calcium looping for CO2 capture from power generation systems has been published by Hanak et al.209 In addition, due to the world's increasing demand for clean energy hydrogen, more CaO is being utilized for sorption-enhanced hydrogen production, such as methane reforming glycerol reforming,222 ethanol reforming, tar reforming, and biomass pyrolysis-gasification. These hydrogen-producing reactions usually involve two processes, SR and WGS, which are generally reversible. By extracting CO2 from the mixture, the equilibrium is shifted to the product side (Le Chatelier's principle), resulting in higher H2 yield. Furthermore, CaO carbonation is an exothermic reaction; thus, the incorporation of the CO2 capture reaction is favorable for the endothermic SR reaction. Moreover, it even turns the SEMR into an exothermic reaction. With these merits, bi-functional CaO-supported catalysts, for example Ni/CaO, were developed for sorption-enhanced hydrogen production. However, bulk CaO still suffers from sharp CO2 uptake reduction caused by sintering and the general solution is to add supports, as mentioned above. Wu223 and Arif224 also believed that the addition of CaO carrier and inert materials (alkaline earth oxides) inhibits the formation of coke, which remains the most serious problem for Ni-based catalysts as it causes a severe decay in the activity. Though noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Rh have better catalytic activity and anti-coking properties,224 lower cost transition metals such as Ni with high catalytic activity are deemed to possess more research value. Charisiou et al.222 reported a Ni/CaO–MgO–Al2O3 (Ni/modAl) catalyst for combined catalytic glycerol steam reforming and in situ CO2 removal. The modAl material with reduced nickel species particle size of higher dispersion exhibited high resistance to coke formation and CaO sintering, leading to enhanced and efficient glycerol conversion and hydrogen production with high purity.


2.4.1.6 Summary and outlook of CaO-based adsorbents. To realize the industrial application of CaO-based sorbents, the activity, price, stability, form, and anti-crush strength need to be taken into full consideration, as shown in Fig. 32. Though the CO2 sorption capacity and cycling stability of synthetic CaO have made great progress, their implementation is still limited by the high cost and poor stability. The performance of CaO derived from cheap precursors is still far from satisfactory, and more importantly, the CO2 uptake of CaO suffers a serious decline after granulation. Hence, the implications of future research should be focused on the following directions: (1) the large-scale preparation technology of CaO with higher sorption capacity and stability derived from solid waste/mineral as well as catalyst-loading techniques for sorption-enhanced hydrogen production; (2) the technology of material regeneration and CO2 separation/purification; (3) direct utilization/conversion technique of CO2 fixed by CaO sorbents.
Fig. 32 The current problems and solutions to realize the industrial application of CaO-based CO2 sorbents211,215,217,219 (Reproduced from ref. 217 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 211 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 219 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2019).
2.4.2 Alkali silicate-based sorbents. Alkali silicates, mainly including lithium silicates and sodium silicate, can act as efficient CO2 sorbents. However, considering the technical requirements for practical applications (such as high sorption capacity, good regeneration performance, and fast sorption/desorption kinetics), not all the aforementioned sorbents are suitable. For instance, the sorption capacity of Na2SiO3 is typically less than 10 wt%. On the contrary, Li8SiO6 exhibits very high sorption capacity (about 50 wt%) and fast kinetics. Unfortunately, the poor regeneration performance hinders its application potential.225 In contrast to Na2SiO3 and Li8SiO6, Li4SiO4 not only has a high sorption capacity (36.5 wt%) but also possesses good regeneration ability.226 Therefore, as the representative of alkali silicate-based CO2 sorbents, Li4SiO4 will be highlighted in this section.86
2.4.2.1 Basic principle and current challenges of Li4SiO4. CO2 can react with Li4SiO4 at high temperatures (>400 °C) to produce Li2CO3 and Li2SiO3 (eqn (4)). The generally-accepted sorption theory is based on the double-shell model. As depicted in Fig. 33, the CO2 capture process includes two steps: (1) CO2 reacts with Li+ at the surface of Li4SiO4 and the products (Li2CO3 and Li2SiO3) can cover the Li4SiO4 surface to form a dense shell with a fast reaction rate; (2) CO2 and Li+ must penetrate this dense product shell in order to react with each other. However, the carbonate shell is not easy to diffuse; thus, the sorption rate in this step diminishes rapidly. As the product shell thickness increases, the reaction gradually stops for CO2 and Li+ cannot penetrate within this shell. The strategies that can improve the CO2 diffusion or Li+ and O2− ion transportation will therefore be extremely effective for CO2 sorption performance of Li4SiO4. Furthermore, the cost of the sorbents is also to be taken into account.
 
Li4SiO4(s) + CO2(g) ↔ Li2CO3(s) + Li2SiO3(s)(4)
Fig. 33 Double shell model for CO2 sorption over Li4SiO4 (Reproduced from ref. 227 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2016).

Hereunder, we have aimed to provide an overview of the optimization methods and their corresponding principles. At the same time, the future application prospect of Li4SiO4 has been evaluated. We hope that this part can provide guidance for the development of alkali silicate-based sorbents. The specific strategies to improve the Li4SiO4 sorption performance are summarized in Fig. 34, including the selection of a proper silicon source, influence of the preparation method, and the addition of foreign materials. For practical applications, the prilling process for making pelletized Li4SiO4 is also of great importance.


Fig. 34 Different strategies for improving the Li4SiO4 sorption performance226–231 (Reproduced from ref. 227 with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright 2016; reproduced from ref. 226 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2017; reproduced from ref. 228 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018; reproduced from ref. 229 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2015; reproduced from ref. 230 with permission from Springer Nature, copyright 2015; reproduced from ref. 231 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018).

2.4.2.2 Strategies for improving the performance of Li4SiO4. According to the aforementioned optimization strategies, there are mainly four ways to enhance the CO2 capture property of Li4SiO4: (1) proper selection of the raw material and preparation methods; (2) creation of more pores by the addition of pore forming agents, (3) surface modification of Li4SiO4 with molten salts, (4) using Si-containing minerals as precursors and utilizing the impurity phases to enhance the stability and to prevent sintering. For the traditional solid-state method, an ideal calcination temperature is typically about 950 °C. During the solid-state process, SiO2 with a high melting point (about 1650 °C) as a “core” material gradually reacts with lithium salts with lower melting points (usually below 800 °C). The reaction progresses from the outside layer of SiO2 to the inside. Hence, large SiO2 particles lead to an increase in the Li4SiO4 particle size. In addition, the large particle size of the raw materials will raise the synthesis temperature and induce a non-uniform reaction, which would undoubtedly facilitate the sintering of Li4SiO4 particles, thus raising the probability of by-product (Li2SiO3 or Li2O) formation. Therefore, an optimization of the raw silica source is crucial.

At present, Li4SiO4 sorbents can be synthesized from a large panel of silica sources, such as zeolites or fumed silica. Compared to commercial silica, these novel silica sources exhibit smaller particle sizes and high SSAs. As a consequence, the formed Li4SiO4 sorbents demonstrate outstanding CO2 capture performances. As shown in Fig. 35a, SBA-15–Li4SiO4226 achieved the highest sorption capacity of 36.3 wt%, which is very close to the maximum theoretical sorption capacity (36.7 wt%). Likewise, MCM-41–Li4SiO4 showed excellent cycling stability during 20 cycles.232 However, high cost and complex synthesis remain the main drawbacks for the practical use of these new silica sources. Hence, some waste materials or natural minerals containing silicon have also been used as raw materials to both reduce the cost and promote waste valorization. Recently, lithium precursors such as Li2CO3, LiNO3, LiOH, and few organometallic salts have also been used as Li-precursors.233 The use of LiOH as a lithium source can significantly decrease the synthesis temperature to 600 °C, thanks to its higher reactivity than that of Li2CO3 and LiNO3.233


Fig. 35 (a) Li4SiO4 synthesis from SBA-15 zeolite (Reproduced from ref. 226 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2017), (b) Li4SiO4 obtained by sol–gel method (Reproduced from ref. 234 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2017), and (c) Li4SiO4 modification by adding TiO2 nanotubes and porous carbon (Reproduced from ref. 235 with permission from American Chemical Society, copyright 2017; reproduced from ref. 236 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2016).

To decrease the preparation temperature and time, novel processing methods have been developed in recent years, including sol–gel method,237 impregnation-precipitation method, glycine-nitrate solution combustion method, and “solvo-plasma” technique.234 Nano-sized or special morphological ceramic materials could be synthesized via these methods. The fine powder or fast heating of raw materials greatly diminished the sintering. In contrast, the conventional solid-state method can only obtain micron-size ceramic particles. Recently, Li4SiO4 nanowire sorbent was firstly synthesized using the “solvo-plasma” technique (Fig. 35b).234 The fabricated sorbent demonstrated a fast sorption rate (sorption capacity reaches 25 wt% in 3 min) and a high sorption capacity (about 35 wt%) due to the high SSA of the nanowires. Unfortunately, serious sintering issues related to the nanowire morphology led to difficult regeneration.

Back-up technical solutions have been set involving ball milling or hydration-calcination method as auxiliary technologies so as to intimately mix raw materials, thus further enhancing the SSA of the as-obtained Li4SiO4 powder.238 The addition of pore forming agents is another strategy to raise the porosity and the SSA of the adsorbent. Pore forming agents generally include carbon materials, organic materials, or porous materials with excellent thermal stability at high temperatures. Carbon and, in general, organic materials become volatile at high synthesis temperature and result in pore formation. In contrast, thermally stable porous materials still remain within the samples, thus generating a secondary porous network. The presence of these pores does not only enhance the mass transfer phenomena but also increases the contact area between the reactants. For instance, TiO2 nanotubes, polyethylene, and porous carbon have been used to design Li4SiO4 sorbents (Fig. 35c).

The main reason for the limitation of the CO2 capture capacity is the dense shell composed of carbonated products (Li2CO3 and Li2SiO3) covering the unreacted core of Li4SiO4. The loading of molten salts, mainly consisting of single, binary, or ternary alkali metal salts, is an effective way to promote the diffusion of CO2 and ions. Indeed, it can form low-temperature eutectic compounds with Li2CO3 and further cause the formation of a “liquid product shell”. Compared with the solid state, the ‘molten state’ is more conducive for the diffusion of CO2 and ions. Hence, this strategy greatly improves the sorption property of Li4SiO4 at low temperatures and CO2 concentration. Zhang et al.232 proved that compared with pure Li4SiO4, the sorption capacity of 10 wt% Na2CO3-loaded Li4SiO4 was increased from 10.8 to 34.7 wt% at 550 °C under 20 vol% CO2.

The surface modification of Li4SiO4 is usually aimed to improve the diffusion capacity of CO2. However, the influence of ion migration on the property of Li4SiO4 sorbents cannot be neglected. The point defects as a result of charge compensation can be formed by the doping of ions into the crystal lattice, which would enhance the ion hopping ability. Recent studies have confirmed that a solid solution can be formed by doping Al, Fe, Na, Ti, Ge, etc., with Li4SiO4via the isomorphous substitution of Si4+ or Li+ in the Li4SiO4 crystal lattice.230,239 Among these solid solutions, Li4+xSi1−xAlxO4 has been widely studied due to its CO2 sorption capacity, compared with Li4SiO4, which can be efficiently improved at medium temperature ranges (e.g., 400–600 °C). Furthermore, a recent study showed that the solid solution of Li4SiO4 doped with Ge (Li4SixGe1−xO4) exhibited excellent sorption performance at a wider operational temperature range (150–680 °C).240

However, the mechanism of promoting the sorbent performance by the addition of other elements is complex and still under debate. For example, Al and Ca react with lithium or silicon to form by-products, such as LiAlO2 or Ca2SiO4, which can then improve the sorption capacity as the promoters in the Li4SiO4 sorbent. The addition of a certain amount of CeO2 can inhibit the aggregation of Li4SiO4 crystals and obtain foam-like Li4SiO4 with improved sorption rate and capacity. The addition of Na, Ti, or Br can also inhibit the growth at the grain boundaries and avoid changes in the morphology of Li4SiO4.230 Besides, doping with sintering-resistant materials (Y2O3 or Gd2O3) also enhances the regeneration performance of the sorbent, thanks to the higher dispersion of Li4SiO4 particles.240 Recently, silicon sources from cheap wastes or minerals has aroused intensive interest, such as blast furnace slag,241 fly ash, diatomite, rice husk ash, halloysite, sediment,242 and biomass ash. Pure SiO2 can be obtained after treatment with acids. However, acid waste solution generated by this process can cause secondary pollution. The sorption performance of the obtained Li4SiO4 is similar to the sorbent synthesized by purified SiO2 or even worse, and the regeneration performance is not significantly improved. To avoid acid pollution, Wang et al.243 used an acid solution, which was produced using the natural silicon source (vermiculite) acid treatment to synthesize Mg–Al LDH. In this new route, two kinds of CO2 sorbents were obtained (Li4SiO4 and Mg–Al LDH) while avoiding pollution due to waste acid liquids. This study also demonstrated that metal oxide impurities that exist in vermiculite as dispersants can improve the cycling performance of Li4SiO4. Furthermore, Li4SiO4 synthesized by BFS-derived silica gel exhibited a fast sorption rate and stable sorption capacity in different CO2 concentration atmospheres (5–100 vol%). The presence of Ti4+ and Al3+ in BFS can improve the CO2 uptake performance (Fig. 36a).241


Fig. 36 (a) Schematic diagram of the mechanism (replacement of Li+ by foreign ions) (Reproduced from ref. 241 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2019), (b) CO2 sorption isotherms of vermiculite–Li4SiO4 and SiO2–Li4SiO4 sorbents under different CO2 concentrations (100 vol%, 50 vol%, 20 vol%) at 550 °C, and (c) the schematic illustration of the synthesis of a Li4SiO4-based CO2 sorbent from a vermiculite precursor (Reproduced from ref. 228 with permission from Elsevier, copyright 2018).

As a natural mineral, vermiculite possesses a higher silicon content (about 40%) than fly ash, and also contains various alkaline earth metals and alkali metals (Mg, Al, K, etc.). Li4SiO4 synthesized by vermiculite exhibited high sorption capacity (20.7 wt%) and excellent sorption stability under different operating conditions. As shown in Fig. 36b, the vermiculite–Li4SiO4 sorption capacity only declined by 0.8 wt% (from 19.4 to 18.6 wt%) with the reduction of CO2 concentration from 100 to 20 vol%, whilst the traditional SiO2–Li4SiO4 capture capacity deteriorated rapidly. This result may be attributed to the porous structure and alkali metals that the adsorbent inherits from vermiculite. Though the sorption capacity of vermiculite–Li4SiO4 is still lower than that of Li4SiO4 prepared by pure SiO2 reagent, the excellent cycling performance and sorption capacity at low CO2 concentrations is warranted for industrial applications. The porous structure of vermiculite–Li4SiO4 can exhibit reduced mass transfer limitation for CO2 diffusion. Likewise, the alkali metal oxides in vermiculite not only promote the CO2 sorption capacity but also prevent the sintering of the particles (Fig. 36c).

Recently, Wang et al.244 synthesized a new nanoparticle/flaker composite silicon source, which was able to adjust the silicon content. For this silicon source, vermiculite and MCM-41 mesoporous silica were connected by the hydrothermal method. The prepared Li4SiO4 presented high SSA (6.8 m2 g−1) and high crystallinity with the even dispersion of alkali metals or alkali earth metals from vermiculite. These characteristics had a positive effect on the adsorption property of Li4SiO4. Compared with Li4SiO4 sorbents obtained from single silicon sources, (MCM-41/vermiculite)–Li4SiO4 demonstrated a higher CO2 sorption capacity at low temperature and low CO2 concentration, reaching 26.1 wt% at 550 °C under 20 vol% CO2. Furthermore, the sorption capacity was slightly diminished by about 1.4 wt% after 20 cycles. In general, a sufficiently high SiO2 content, the presence of moderate amounts of thermally stable impurities, and the presence of alkali or alkaline compounds are necessary (but probably not sufficient) features for silicon precursors to fabricate efficient Li4SiO4 sorbents.


2.4.2.3 Perspectives and outlook of alkali silicate-based sorbents. Recently, the demand of a high-temperature CO2 sorbent gradually increased with the SEHP process development. In this process, CO2 as the by-product, is generated simultaneously with H2, which greatly affects the H2 purity and limits the production rate when the equilibrium is gradually reached. It is therefore mandatory to introduce a suitable CO2 sorbent into the process to shift the equilibrium for improved H2 purity yield and reduced energy consumption. However, the presence of SO2, NOx, and H2O in the flue gas further raise the complexity of post-combustion CO2 capture. The post-combustion CO2 capture process by using high temperature CO2 sorbent is considered as an effective way to reduce CO2 emissions. Pacciani et al.245 proved that the existence of SO2 in the flue gas will cause the deactivation of lithium-based sorbents due to the irreversible reaction between Li4SiO4 and SO2. Therefore, removing SO2 is mandatory prior to CO2 capture. There is no clear decrease in the CO2 sorption capacity over Li4SiO4 in the 0–1000 ppm NO concentration range due to the chemical inertia of NO with Li4SiO4. In contrast, the presence of steam in flue gas sorption conditions can promote CO2 capture of Li4SiO4 for the enhanced diffusion of Li+. The industrial applications require prilling of Li4SiO4 powder, which is the last step in sample preparation after the different steps involved in the optimization of the Li4SiO4 sorbent. Though the study of granulation technology of Li4SiO4 is limited, promising results could be obtained using extrusion-spheronization, agar method, and graphite moulding pelletization method. Considering that the particle size of the sorbent increases rapidly after granulation, the addition of a pore-forming agent in the prilling process is therefore necessary to reduce the diffusion resistance of CO2. For the Li4SiO4 sorbent, the optimization of synthetic conditions and methods greatly improve the sorption capacity under pure CO2 atmosphere. However, the CO2 concentration in practical applications are varied in a wide range. Thus, improving the regeneration performance and sorption capacity at low CO2 concentration are of paramount importance. In addition, the impact of the complex compositions in the flue gas, such as fly ash, SO2, and H2O, on the Li4SiO4 sorbent performance should be assessed in a more systematic manner. In addition, the granulation of the Li4SiO4 powder needs to be considered due to the difficulties in using and recycling the powder in a machine. However, there are few reports about it at present.
2.4.3 Alkali titanate-based sorbents. Traditional solid chemical CO2 sorbents, such as CaO-based, alkali silica-based, and alkali zirconate-based sorbents, have been widely investigated in terms of the sorption performance and modification. However, in addition to material modification, the proposal of a new capturing material has also attracted widespread attention due to the improved cycling stability and other limitations. A variety of novel materials have been proposed for high-temperature CO2 chemisorption in recent years. Nevertheless, the sintering effect over multiple sorption-desorption processes still largely restricts the development of these materials. Meanwhile, a new promising CO2 capture material, alkali titanate-based sorbent with a similar structure to that of silicate- and zirconate-based sorbents, has shown selective CO2 sorption capacity and great potential for high-temperature CO2 capture. The titanates possessed a typical layered structure with a chemical formula of MxTiyOx/2+2y·zH2O (M = H, Li, Na, K, etc.). Similar to other layered materials, these titanates have a 2D sheet structure formed by Ti and O atoms, with cations or neutral molecules located inside the layers’ spaces. A majority of layers consist of many edge-sharing TiO6 octahedral blocks, such as H2Ti3O7 and K2Ti6O13. There are still a few titanates possessing different Ti atom- coordinated structures. For example, K2Ti2O5 exhibits a unique layered structure, which has a five-fold coordination structure and then forms the 2D (Ti2O5)2− sheets.246
2.4.3.1 Progress in alkali titanate-based sorbents. Alkali titanate-based materials were used for low-temperature CO2 capture at first. However, over the past decades, significant research efforts have been devoted to the development of alkali titanate-based sorbents, particularly for the SESR processes of pre-combustion CO2 capture. By overcoming the reaction equilibrium limitation, it is possible to achieve the complete conversion of CH4 or CO by the sorption by a solid CO2 sorbent. Initially, the performance of CO2 sorption and desorption capacities was investigated over Li4TiO4 at high temperatures. Li4TiO4 can adsorb CO2 from a lower temperature (250 °C) to about 900 °C and shows a significantly fast sorption rate promotion at 710 °C. The weight increase was approximately 27 wt% at 710 °C during continuous heating and carbonization, with the formation of Li2TiO3 and Li2CO3. Besides, CO2 uptake increased with the decreasing diameter of the sorbents. However, this material suffers from poor stability over repeated cycles due to increased particle size and decreased reactive SSA. Moreover, the prepared Li4TiO4 deteriorates easily when exposed to the atmosphere.

Sodium titanate is widely used in various fields, such as catalysis and wastewater treatment,247 and has been utilized as a possible CO2 sorbent in the recent years. Furthermore, potassium titanates, especially potassium dititanate (K2Ti2O5), have also been systematically investigated for their CO2 capture capacity, reaction kinetics, and regeneration ability. In contrast to other sorption materials suffering from serious sintering problems due to high temperature operation condition of multiple cycles, K2Ti2O5 showed a typical particle size “break-down” process. The morphology cracked down into K2Ti2O5 nanofibers instead of bulk particles at high temperature after 20 cycles. Thanks to the morphological changes, CO2 uptake was increased in the first few cycles and then finally reached a plateau. In addition, K2Ti2O5 showed a dramatic improvement in reversible structure switching during the CO2 sorption/desorption processes (Fig. 37). A rapid and complete release of captured CO2 can be achieved within only 6.0 min at the same temperature (750 °C).246


Fig. 37 The proposed CO2 sorption and desorption mechanism over K2Ti2O5 caused by reversible structure switching.246
